stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on designing and texturing the new 'Oily Boily Bay' level (Course 11), collaborates with artist Biobak to implement a new, animated power meter, and discusses significant reworks of camera controls and earlier courses.

development_findings.summary: The camera controls were overhauled to address input lag complaints. C-buttons now provide instant rotation, while the D-pad allows for slower, controlled rotation.
development_findings.quote: Holding to rotate is gone. But instead on the D-pad, you can hold to rotate slowly like this.

development_findings.summary: Based on a viewer's suggestion, Kaze implemented smooth scaling and filling animations for the new power meter, improving its visual feedback.
development_findings.quote: Emitter should scale in when it appears and refilling it should be smooth instead of just instantly adding a chunk. Yeah, I like that... I can do that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explained the technical method for the smooth circular breath meter, which uses a circular gradient texture to control the alpha threshold of the visible meter.
development_findings.quote: The breath meter's progress is achieved using an alpha threshold technique on two textures.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejected adding smoother transitional animations between states like idle and run, prioritizing 'snappy' and responsive controls over fluid animation.
development_findings.quote: I think I won't make it Mario's movement less snappy so I don't really want that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze revealed a dream about Toads playing instruments inspired a new collectible feature: finding three hidden Toads in the overworlds will unlock a special song.
Multiple early-game courses, including Course 2/8, have been completely reworked since the demo, featuring improved level design, better camera behavior, and higher framerates.
The team may adopt a new N64 microcode that allows disabling near clipping, which could be a significant technical solution to persistent camera problems.
development_findings.quote: I've also been told about a new microcode today that we might want to use... it allows you to disable near clipping so that would solve some of our camera issues.

development_findings.summary: The player's breath meter is intentionally shorter than in the original SM64 to enforce level design and prevent players from bypassing challenges without using intended mechanics.
development_findings.quote: I guess the reason I wanted it shorter than vanilla is because in this level you'd be able to just get everywhere. And I don't want that to happen.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes efficient use of matrix animations allows his N64 project to outperform even GameCube titles like Mario Sunshine in certain aspects, like NPC count.
development_findings.quote: I can render more moving npcs on my n64 than mario sunshine could on the gamecube... I think the difference is in how efficient the matrix math is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is committed to creating a serious, high-quality game experience, deliberately avoiding transient meme culture to build something with lasting value.
context_findings.quote: This is a game, not a meme. You might say I'm stuck up for actually making sure that my game is not just a meme, but this is what I want in my life.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong personal investment in the game's color theory and overall aesthetic, indicating that visual harmony is a core design principle for him.
context_findings.quote: I care a lot about making the colors work together in a way that is satisfying.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong, unconventional belief that a fundamental understanding of low-level programming (Assembly) is essential before learning higher-level languages like C.
context_findings.quote: Learning C before you've learned assembly is like explaining color to a blind person.

context_findings.summary: Kaze maintains an intense work ethic, balancing a full-time job as a professional game programmer with his passion project, often working 70-hour weeks.
context_findings.quote: I don't mind working 70-hour weeks. I'm kind of just a little different.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's life and worldview are deeply intertwined with Super Mario 64, using its release as a major life event marker.
context_findings.quote: It's actually insane Mario 64 is so much of my life that I do categorize people into being born before and after Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze critiques other media (like the anime Re:Zero) for having poor character writing, stating he derives more joy from world-building and interesting settings than relatable characters.

biobak.summary: Biobak designed the new power meter UI, collaborating closely and iteratively with Kaze to perfect its color palette and visual properties.
biobak.quote: Me and Biobak, we went through a lot of back and forth to get these colors exactly right. Because I didn't want the brightness to increase from blue to green.

biobak.summary: During the stream, Biobak created and sent Kaze a custom Bowser logo to be used on the tower in Course 11.
Biobak needed clarification on N64 technical limitations, such as texture dimensions (128x64) and their impact on color depth (16 shades of gray).

zeina.summary: Zeina shows support for Kaze's intense work schedule, discussing how she would manage meals if he were to stream for eight hours a day during a vacation.
zeina.quote: Listen if we're streaming when you're on vacation and you're streaming every day. I gotta make sure I meal prep properly.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze share playful banter about their personal lives and cooking skills, revealing a comfortable and humorous dynamic.
zeina.quote: I've been saying you can't cook since I married you.

zeina.summary: Zeina participated in rescuing a baby bird with Kaze, an event they both recounted on stream, offering a glimpse into their shared life outside of game development.

key_stories.title: The Power Meter Redesign
key_stories.summary: The team collaborated on a complete overhaul of the power meter. Artist Biobak and programmer Kaze worked iteratively to solve a color theory challenge, and Kaze implemented the new assets live on stream, adding extra animation polish based on community feedback.
key_stories.challenge: The game's power meter needed a visual and functional redesign. A key artistic challenge was creating a color gradient that didn't have a jarring increase in perceived brightness.
key_stories.process: Biobak designed the new UI sprites, collaborating with Kaze through multiple iterations to finalize the colors. During the stream, Kaze received the final assets, coded their implementation, and then quickly added custom animations for appearing and refilling.
key_stories.outcome: A new, clean, 32x32 power meter was successfully implemented. Kaze also added smooth scaling and refilling animations based on viewer feedback, resulting in a polished UI element.
key_stories.key_quote: Me and Biobak, we went through a lot of back and forth to get these colors exactly right. Because I didn't want the brightness to increase from blue to green.

key_stories.title: The Dream-Inspired Toads
key_stories.summary: Kaze turned a bizarre dream about poorly-playing musical Toads into a new collectible feature. This demonstrates how his creative process can be fueled by his subconscious, translating abstract ideas into tangible game mechanics.
key_stories.challenge: A dream about Toads playing instruments gave Kaze an interesting but undefined idea for a new game feature.
key_stories.process: Kaze had a strange dream, reflected on the concept, and decided to adapt its core theme into a concrete, optional gameplay mechanic that adds charm and replayability to the overworld.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze formalized the idea into a new collectible system: three Toads will be hidden across the game's overworlds, and finding all of them will unlock a special musical performance.
key_stories.key_quote: In my dream I had put four totes over my game... And you know what? I'm kinda doing this. I decided we're kinda gonna do this.

key_stories.title: Naming 'Oily Boily Bay'
key_stories.summary: While designing a new Bowser level, Kaze and his community workshopped a name. The process revealed Kaze's specific naming conventions and his appreciation for goofy, fun-to-say titles, resulting in the temporary name 'Oily Boily Bay'.
key_stories.challenge: The new oil rig level, Course 11, needed a name that fit the project's established convention of alliteration or rhyme.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed name ideas with his chat, rejecting several more serious suggestions. He fixated on finding a rhyming or alliterative name, eventually landing on 'Oily Boily Bay' and defending it as 'goofy, but it works'.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze temporarily settled on 'Oily Boily Bay'. Despite acknowledging its silliness, he embraced it because it was memorable, fun to say, and met his criteria, demonstrating his preference for charm over seriousness.
key_stories.key_quote: Oily Boily Bay. What else can we use that rhymes with oily and boily, maybe non-bay. Oily Boily Coily, we're not going with toilet.
